content.description: Predicting the possible outcomes of program (2017 Spring, Final, Question 9 c)

p.line: We've always appreciated how easily Python handles functions as data. There's no _BOLDS_call, run_BOLDE_ or _BOLDS_launch_BOLDE_ block, you can just receive a function as a parameter and call it directly. This gives us an idea. You remember when we talked in lecture about how _BOLDS_combine_BOLDE_ should always work if you're given an associative dyadic (twoinput) function, and how it paired its values up was below the abstraction line (i.e., you shouldn't know about it)? It could evaluate it any way it wants and the answer should still be the same. For example, if given + on a list of 5 elements A through E, it could return ((((A+B)+C)+D)+E) or ((A + ((B + C) + D)) + E) etc, and it will all work because + is an associative dyadic function. Taking that to heart, we've rewritten _BOLDS_combine_BOLDE_ (as _BOLDS_mycombine_BOLDE_) below that finds a random adjacent pair of elements, calls its function _BOLDS_f_BOLDE_ on them and puts the result back in line:
(note _BOLDS_randint_BOLDE_ below is inclusive of its endpoints, so _BOLDS_randint(1, 3)_BOLDE_ might return 1,2, or 3)
_BOLDS__BLANK__BLANK_L = data[:] _BOLDE_## make a copy of the input
_BOLDS__BLANK__BLANK__BLANK__BLANK_index = random.randint(0,len(L)-2) _BOLDE_ ## pick a random index (not the end)
_BOLDS__BLANK__BLANK__BLANK__BLANK_L[index]=f(L[index],L[index+1]) _BOLDE_ ## replace element with call to f
_BOLDS__BLANK__BLANK__BLANK__BLANK_L.pop(index+1) _BOLDE_ ## delete the one to the right
_BOLDS__BLANK__BLANK_return L[0] _BOLDE_ ## return the listâ€™s only element
What are all the return values of mycombine(minus,[4,3,2,1])? (select all that apply)

content.hint: Consider the possibilities of the orders of combination. That is equivalent with having 4, 3, 2, 1 in a line, and by adding "-" and "(", ")" to the numbers and making an equation, see how many different results can we get.
